Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Instrumentation (LC-MS/MS) for the Trace Analysis of Anthropogenic Organic Compounds and Their Metabolites in Various Complex Matrices

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

#1228662
P.I.: Guangshu Zhai

This proposed instrument will support the body of research at The University of Iowa on trace organic compounds and their metabolites in the environment and living organisms by increasing capacity and capabilities. This instrument will allow in-depth studies within our ongoing projects, including the transport and fate of hormones in plants (Zhai and Schnoor), hydroxylated metabolites of PCBs in poplars (Zhai and Schnoor), rats (Robertson) and human blood (Hornbuckle); organic pollutants by extreme flood events (Hornbuckle, Just, Schnoor); PCBs sulfate metabolites of PCBs in poplars (Zhai and Schnoor), rats (Robertson and Duffel); the enantioselective metabolism of chiral PCBs and their metabolites (Zhai, Schnoor, and Lehlmer); PCB-related compounds in the environment (Hornbuckle, Lehmler, Thorne) and others. All the organic compounds mentioned above have the potential of great harm to our health and environment. All the researchers in this team will use this LC-MS/MS to address many public concerns on the health of environment and human beings. All the findings of these researches will greatly advance our knowledge and understanding of the behavior, fate and toxicological mechanisms of organic pollutants in the environment and alert people to take suitable protective measures.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
A high performance liquid chromatograph (with autosampler) tandem triple quadrupole mass spectrometer system (HPLC/MS/MS) (Agilent 1260LC-6460 Triple Quad MS) with its workstation, and a nitrogen generator (Peak Scientific) were purchased after a careful comparison of different HPLC/MS/MS models from various companies using funds from this MRI grant. The instrumentation is located in the lab of Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, the University of Iowa, and will be used for the detection and quantification of anthropogenic organic compounds and their metabolites in various complex matrices in our research and teaching activities at The University of Iowa.

This instrument is now being utilized for a number of different research studies. We are investigating the fate of organic compounds, including PCBs, flame retardants and their metabolites in plant tissues; the hydroxylated metabolites of PCBs in environmental and biological samples (soils, blood, water, and air); hydroxylated PCBs, sulfate-metabolites of PCBs and glucuronide-metabolites of PCBs metabolites in rat tissues. This instrument
is also openly available to other researchers. Many researchers from The University of Iowa, including professors, research scientists, post-Docs, Ph.D. students and Master of Science students, use this instrument to analyze various environmental products which would not have been possible earlier. We will focus on environmental organic pollutants in water, air, soil, plant, animal, and human urine and blood, in studies related to human and environmental health. New findings via this instrument will benefit graduate and undergraduate student theses at the University of Iowa. This instrument will also provide direct broader impacts on people in the State of Iowa because many of the environmental samples are taken throughout Iowa. Data produced by this instrument will provide some context for organic pollutants in Iowa, which can alert people to avert or avoid exposure in the future. Hence, our society will benefit from analyses using this instrument.


Last Modified: 11/08/2013
Modified by: Guangshu Zhai
